title: Relative Major & Minor
description: Discover the relationship between major and minor keys that share the same notes.

steps.title: Relative Keys
steps.description: Every major key has a 'relative minor' that uses the exact same notes — just starting from a different place. The relative minor starts on the 6th note of the major scale. For C major, the 6th note is A, so A minor is C major's relative minor.

steps.title: Play C Major
steps.description: Play the C major scale: C-D-E-F-G-A-B.
steps.hint: All white keys from C to B.

steps.title: Play A Natural Minor
steps.description: Now play A natural minor: A-B-C-D-E-F-G. Same notes as C major, different starting point!
steps.hint: All white keys from A to G — same notes as C major!

steps.title: Finding the Relative Minor
steps.description:
To find any major key's relative minor, go down 3 semitones (or up to the 6th note):

• C major → A minor
• G major → E minor
• D major → B minor
• F major → D minor

They share the same key signature — same sharps and flats!

steps.title: C Major (Home of the Major Key)
steps.description: Play C major — this is the 'home' chord in C major.

steps.title: A Minor (Home of the Relative Minor)
steps.description: Play A minor — the 'home' chord in A minor. Same notes available, different emotional center.
